Love the game, over 100 hours in, but summoning is pretty busted. For a ranged or melee build, the mechanic of having to manage summons by constantly firing off a summon that lasts a minute or two (just to have an added damage source) seems reasonable. That micromanaging is NOT reasonable for a dedicated summoner.

Summon armor absolutely needs to be adjusted so summons get [permanence] while wearing a set, not just an extra minute or two via rings and such. If someone wants to sacrifice defense with the goal of allowing a horde of summons to do the work, then those summons should be out 24/7. 

Or just make summons permanent and give summon armors even more summon count. Anything would be better than the ridiculous micromanaging that summoning requires right now.

[b]Core Keeper is a crafting/building game about expansive exploration, in a beautiful but unfamiliar underground world.[/b]

[h3]What you'll want to know:[/h3]
[list]The [b]core gameplay mechanics are presented to the player within the first 30 minutes, and it rarely ever deviates from them[/b]. The variety comes from finding more items, biomes, and bosses as you push outwards.
[b]If you don't enjoy the gameplay during the first hour, you won't later.[/b][/list]
[list]It's great with friends, but it plays completely fine solo.[/list]
[list][b]There's a lot of exploration, but you need to lean heavily on the progression mechanics in the game.[/b][/list]
[list]The combat in the game is very fast. There are times where you get killed within a few seconds. You have to learn to slow down and use mechanics like cooking and armour to mitigate this.[/list]


[h3]Things I loved:[/h3]
[list]The music and graphics are truly works of art.[/list]
[list]The mechanics are uncomplicated, intuitive and polished[/list]
[list]Crafting using nearby containers, and a single button to quick stack.[/list]
[list]An abundance of items. You'll need lots of chests.[/list]
[list]Numerous viable approaches to movement and combat[/list]

[h3]Things I liked:[/h3]
[list]Chill time at base doesn't feel wasted. There's always something you can do or build between ventures.[/list]

[h3]Things I disliked:[/h3]
[list]Pacing slows down dramatically during the second act.[/list]
[list]The game ends pretty anticlimactically.[/list]
[list]Ctrl+scroll wheel to swap inventory layers is neat but becomes overwhelming.[/list]
[list]Huge amount of [b]inter-biome[/b] variety, but not a lot of [i]intra-biome[/i] variety[/list]
[list]Thankfully not a lot of resource grinding, but you are expected to have collected some obscure items.[/list]
[list]hard mode doesn't add as much in-game reward as it suggests.[/list]

[h3]Things I hated:[/h3]
[list]Font is egregious. I honestly gave up on cooking because it's so hard to read the font.[/list]

Core Keeper isn't just a game; it's a hole in the ground where my time and social life went to die. I purchased it expecting a cute, casual mining/survival game, and instead, I became a subterranean zealot, driven by the insatiable urge to dig just one more layer and find just one more piece of glittering space-ore.

The Good: The loop is perfect. Digging feels immediately satisfying. The boss fights are genuinely tense and require actual effort (who knew a giant slime could induce so much panic?). And the moment you break through a wall and discover a massive, ancient, glowing biome? Pure dopamine.

The Bad: The inventory management is peak reality simulation. It perfectly captures the feeling of a miner carrying 40,000 pounds of dirt and 3 rotten apples.

The Ugly (But Loveable): You will get catastrophically lost. You will run out of torches. You will panic and accidentally eat your only healing potion while surrounded by sentient mushrooms. And you will love every minute of it.

If you enjoy Terraria, Stardew Valley, or simply losing yourself for 10 hours straight while your house slowly fills with dirt blocks, buy this immediately. But maybe buy a large pizza first. Just in case.

After sitting down and finally seeing all the content Core Keeper has to offer, I feel nothing but burnt out and frustrated. 

To start, the areas are huge and pretty decently designed - aside from the fact that there's just 2-3 enemies per area and that they're vast, empty, and boring most of the time. Have fun hacking away at walls and enemies you've seen hundreds of times over when trying to find an underwhelming structure that gives you items that barely have any functionality or uniqueness to them. I'll give it to them though, a lot of this stuff is super cool and fun to find the first time, but this game has an EXTREMELY bad issue with being repetitive in almost every way after that initial wow factor wears off. Things like a vast array of structures, items, rare enemies, etc, make these types of games fun, and Core Keeper just completely lacks those features. Core Keeper has several mechanics, and nearly all of them feel unfinished to me. Grind, Grind, and Grind some more:
If you love mindless grinding, this is the game for you.

The reason for this is that the acquisition of armor and weapons (outside of a very few select sets, mainly the ore armors) is entirely tied to loot tables on enemies or in the environment. After feeling lost for a few hours, I finally took a look over at the wiki to see what I was missing, and as it turns out, I wasn't missing anything! The game has NO way of crafting gear for ANY of the classes.

As someone who was wowed by the first few hours of the game, I really cannot express how disappointed I am with the experience after a few more hours.

Core Keeper is a cave exploration game that is centered around progression by upgrading your gear and defeating bosses, pretty similarly to Terraria! The game also allows you to flex your creative muscles with some building mechanics, and even has NPCs that you can have move in as well!

Let's start with the good:
The game is visually stunning! The art style perfectly suits it in every way! I found myself eager to explore the beautiful caverns and see all of the diverse biomes where you find all kinds of fantastical creatures! It really is a joy to load up the game as a new player and explore what the early stages of the game has to offer visually!

The music is also incredible! I routinely found myself in awe in the early stages when I would find a new biome and the music would change. It inspired all kinds of feelings of whimsical adventuring/caving. 
(Side Note: I can tell the developers have musical backgrounds by the fact they also put musical puzzles in the game, so it makes sense the music is really good!)

The enemy and boss design is cool! I like the different types of enemies, and I've found many of them to be unique and interesting! (I do wish there were more though)

Unfortunately, that's where the strengths of the game end for me, and the laundry list of problems begin to start.

Mechanics in General:
Core Keeper has several mechanics, and nearly all of them feel unfinished to me. Skill progression is hit or miss, combat is limited for reasons I'll discuss later, building doesn't feel as fleshed out as it could be, the villagers seem relatively uninteresting to me, and the class system really struggles for a major reason I'll discuss later.

Grind, Grind, and Grind some more:
If you love mindless grinding, this is the game for you.
I cannot believe that I am 7 hours into the game, and I'm still grinding for a singular piece of gear to complete the set for my specific class of choice (Mage). The reason for this is that the acquisition of armor and weapons (outside of a very few select sets, mainly the ore armors) is entirely tied to loot tables on enemies or in the environment. After feeling lost for a few hours, I finally took a look over at the wiki to see what I was missing, and as it turns out, I wasn't missing anything! The game has NO way of crafting gear for ANY of the classes.
This might not be so bad, as long as the drop chances are at least pretty forgiving, right? Well, unfortunately, the EARLIEST set of mage gear has a >5% drop rate from every instance you can acquire it from with the exception of a BOSS FIGHT.
I understand that in games like Terraria (A game I quite like), there are some frustrating instances where you have to grind for gear, but for the gear that is essential to progression for your main classes, most of the gear is relatively achievable within a short time frame. I have spent HOURS searching for the FIRST SET of gear for my class of choice.
Also remember, that the drop rate per enemy is equal for each set of armor, meaning that you might find 10 hats and 5 chest pieces, but no pants for instance. Don't even get me started on the weapons. -_-
I would appreciate if, even if the gear is not entirely craftable, there was some way to swap two pieces of gear for one. For instance, maybe I could swap my leggings and chest piece for a hat, or hat and leggings for a chest piece, or some sort of mechanic that minimizes the grind a bit, but alas, there is no mechanic present.

Continuing on the trend of grinding:
In my short time playing the game I can already see how inbalanced progression is among certain skills compared to others. 
Running levels up incredibly fast for something that you do literally all the time in game, but combat skills level up FAR TOO slow for the amount of time you spend doing them relatively. I'm not saying it has to be one to one, but a slightly less grindy balance for earlier levels of these skills would be nice.
Speaking of skills:
The Skill trees feel underwhelming and boring. You spend all of this time shooting magic or your bow at people, and your reward for levelling FIVE levels is (+2% Crit Chance). Come on now. I understand the minor stat boosts for things such as mining and running, but the actual combat skills?

General Takeaways
I've spent a lot of time griping about my largest concerns, so I'll summarize the rest with this:

Similar to Terraria, the game just tosses you in and expects you to figure this s*** out. While Terraria has taken some steps to minimize this, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND consulting the Wiki for this game if you feel lost.

Several other mechanics feel unfinished.
- The Main Biomes don't feel unique to explore. They feel like identical areas but with slightly higher or lower tier ores and a coat of paint.
- There are SO MANY crafting stations, and many of them allow you to craft random assortments of blocks that vary in terms of usefulness. This is particularly frustrating because there are so many cool ideas here, and it feels like the devs either didn't want or didn't have the time to expand on them and make them meaningful.

This is my first ever written review for a game, so sorry if it's a bit scatterbrained, but I found myself needing to get some of my frustrations off of my chest, and potentially bring awareness to some problems that the game has that aren't apparent right away. 

Whether or not you buy is entirely personal preference. If you enjoy mindless grinding and the dopamine hit from finally finding that last piece of gear, this is definitely the game for you. I personally don't find the need to grind this early on and to this scale enjoyable.

After sitting down and finally seeing all the content Core Keeper has to offer, I feel nothing but burnt out and frustrated. 

To start, the areas are huge and pretty decently designed - aside from the fact that there's just 2-3 enemies per area and that they're vast, empty, and boring most of the time. Have fun hacking away at walls and enemies you've seen hundreds of times over when trying to find an underwhelming structure that gives you items that barely have any functionality or uniqueness to them. I'll give it to them though, a lot of this stuff is super cool and fun to find the first time, but this game has an EXTREMELY bad issue with being repetitive in almost every way after that initial wow factor wears off. Things like a vast array of structures, items, rare enemies, etc, make these types of games fun, and Core Keeper just completely lacks those features. It feels like there's a really solid base for them to add onto, and I'm hoping future updates will turn these issues around.

Furthermore, the skill tree is also a glaring issue in this game and almost feels like it's still in beta mode. Something about it is just very linear, boring, and uninspired. You can see everything it offers from the start of the game, and it really doesn't spark any sense of excitement for the later levels. Every 5 levels, you get to put a skill point in each corresponding tree's skills in a very linear fashion. There's really not much more to it than giving you some extra stat bonuses and occasionally a cool effect. Most of the time, one path of the tree is just so obviously better than the other that there's no point in diversifying between playthroughs. It just overall feels half baked and unfun, and in my opinion, needs a COMPLETE overhaul to even remotely feel like a finished feature.

To be clear, first half/early game feels very polished and well designed, but this formula completely falls off at a certain point and just becomes an uninspired grind fest with almost no reward. Items like the soul seeker show how terribly designed parts of this game are. The item is only good for a small portion of the game where it's not even worth grinding for since other mining equipment outclasses it very quickly. So what's the point in spending all of that time and effort searching for the forge and grinding all the bars/materials to craft it? It's just glaring BAD game design that makes 0 sense and doesn't even feel rewarding. I used the rune song for 80% of the game because I was lucky enough to find the stupidly rare structures its components spawn in very early on. I had zero reason to use any other weapon because of how easily this one outclasses everything in the game all the way up to end game. I had fun using it, but it just feels like really half assed game design especially when it's one of the very few interesting items in the game. So, looking at the worlds of difference between these two legendary weapons, you can see a major flaw in their design philosophy. You can get the rune song super early and it outclasses everything, while the soul seeker is a complete waste of time by the time you can get it. It all feels very silly and like they don't understand their own game's progression. And the funniest part - I only had fun because of the rune song and how OP it is because it made the game a bit less of a slog than the last time I had booted up a new world. Not to mention that it's one of the only well designed weapons that have a sense of uniqueness and some cool effects. Most of this game is crafting the same axe, sword, ranged weapon, etc just in a different font. This unfortunately makes the game become repetitive extremely quickly as well as proves as an example of this game not being well-designed as far as equipment goes (for the most part).

Overall, I really want to like Core Keeper, but it falls flat in way too many areas to feel like a finished and entirely fun game. Around 60-70% completion, the game just completely wastes your time in so many ways that it's exhausting. Getting to that next initial wow factor kept me going to the next stage, but in the end, I realized my journey was more unsatisfying and annoying than it was fun, exciting, and challenging. I still recommend trying this game and in no way think it's terrible - it's just mid to OK at best once you've seen the bigger picture, in my opinion. When games like Terraria, tModLoader/Calamity, and Necesse exist, it's hard to say I'll ever truly want to return for more Core Keeper when the other experiences do almost everything entirely better. I see the work that has been put in, and I appreciate it. From the art, music, and general concept. With that said though, I still can't say this is an amazing game in its current state. What I can say, though, is that I think they can easily fix these design flaws with some time, effort, and maybe some design philosophy changes in the future updates. I'm excited to see what's coming in Core Keeper's future, but will not be returning until I see that the game can be a more fulfilling experience until the very end.
